title: Check sequence mismatch only for ordered consumer
body:
Sequence mismatch was checked always for push consumers.
That caused recreating consumers.

Now it does that only for ordered consumers.

title: Export subscription modules
body:
A few types like `nats::jetstream::push_subscription::Handler` were voldemort types.

This exports the `push_subscription` and `pull_subscription` modules to
avoid that scenario.

title: Fix Pull Subscriber visibility
body:
- cherry picked  commit from #311 
- reshuffled methods so docs shows the high-level ones first
- added missing docs for iterator

fixes #311

title: Add a public convenience interface to header maps
body:
This adds an actual API for headers instead of exposing `inner` publicly.

- [x] Add methods for `append`, `insert` and `get`.
- [x] Make inner private, remove all uses of inner internally.
- [x] Lint (ToString is a bit bad here, probably use where Key is `Into<String>` instead)
- [x] Implement `get_all(key: K)`

This is a breaking change.

title: Replace chrono with time due to RUSTSEC-2020-0159
body: Resolves #308.

title: Change jetstream log level to debug
body: Closes #306

title: Join all connect threads while closing connection
body: closes #300

title: Harden kv doctests
body:
Always delete the store when one is created at demo.nats.io.

Resolves #293

title: Jarema/pull subscribe
body:
TODO:

- [x] add expire fetch and no_wait fetch
- [x] Make tests more solid (test max in flight etc)
- [x] Test acks
- [x] check if all validations are in place
- [x] add docs & examples
- [x] check behaviour parity with Go client
- [x] self-review before removing DRAFT
- [x] add methods with auto-ack
- [x] add features from 2.7.0

title: Jarema/fix unsub
body:
All unsubscribe methods were actually draining.
Also, some `drain`s discarded messages, which should not happen.
Added tests.

fixes #297

title: Jarema/add slow consumers
body:
Added handling to slow consumers.

I really don't like the outcome.
Adding the method to return dropped messages (and count them in the first place) forces making some fields of `State` `pub(crate)` to be able to reach them from `Subscription`.

Will make a rework using the preprocessor.

closes #299

title: Fix License
body:
The current license doesn't show up on repo list.
Updated to fix that and also have it in line with other NATS.io repos.

title: Fix lame duck mode tests race
body:
Lame duck mode tests were sometimes failing because of the fact that they were not targeting specific PID.
With each test in parallel, risk of race happening was increasing.

This allows func that calls lame_duck_mode to refer specific PID.

title: Reorganize jetstream module
body:
Merges all jetstream prefixed modules into a single module with sub-modules.
Makes for cleaner documentation and is a step towards a cleaner structure (types.rs is still quite the kitchen sink of things).

title: Add watch and rename watch to watch_all
body:
* add missing function to watch specific keys
* align API for watching over kv with Go client

title: Fix kv watch subject value
body: fixes #284

title: Fix object store tests and run them tests against unstable features
Fix Object read and object_store tests
Improve TLS support
body:
This PR removes custom parsing of .pem files and delegates the work to `rustls-pemfile` which removes another security-related responsibility from this library and adds support for different .pem contents.

fixes #277

title: Introduce ServerAddress
body:
The main change of the PR is turning `fn connect(&str)` into `fn connect<I: IntoServerList>(nats_url: I)`. The reason is to make it more prominent which kind of URLs are expected.
The refactoring in the background also cleans-up some code and makes some decisions more explicit like interpreting a missing scheme as `nats://` or the default port `4222`.

This is the implementation as I initially thought of in #216.

title: Jarema/reorganize kv and object_store modules
body: resolves #272

title: fix: publicly export handler struct
body: Currently the `Handler` struct returned from `Subscription#with_handler` is public but not exported as part of the library. This exports it so the handler can be used as a return type etc.

title: Implement object store
body:
This implements object store.

Note that the ADR has not yet been finalised.

title: Implement key-value store
body: Implements key-value store as per the ADR.

title: Lame duck mode support
body: Realized that we should probably do more when new info arrives, hence used `process_info` instead of more specific name for lame duck tape mode.

title: Workflow improvements
body:
- Remove jetstream job
- Don't use rustup to re-install clippy
- Normalises jobs and step naming splitting them into two groups: tests and checks.

title: Add header module
body:
This makes the header module public which contains the header map type and constants for various known headers (taking a little inspiration from the [http crate](https://docs.rs/http/0.2.5/http/header/index.html) here).

The top level `Headers` type still exists, but has been aliased to the new name and the alias is marked as deprecated.

title: Use temporary directories for storage
body:
Quotes were resulting in a directory named `./$SD` directory to be created and used on Unix for storage, which leads to racing between the tests and frequent failures.

This makes use of the `--store_dir` cli option instead.

title: Have Client in Message as Option
body: Code overview how approach with `Option<Message>` could look like.

title: Revert message refactor
body:
Needs further discussion, naming doesn't quite hit home after seeing it in the "wild".

- Revert "Cleanup crate imports"
- Revert "Refactor Message"

title: Refactor Message
body:
This is first pass of changes in messages.

As I was going back and forth with how to restrict available methods on `BoundMessage` depending on context (JetStream or not) I decided to first include `BoundMessage` with POD `Message` struct.

Next step is to restrict the methods.

title: Some additions..
body:
Added in async error callback with defaults eprintln!
Made Message is_no_responders() public for normal use.

Signed-off-by: Derek Collison <derek@nats.io>

title: Re-work JetStream consumer interface
body:
Adds support for jetstream subscriptions as described by ADR-15 and ordered consumers as described by ADR-17.

There's one defect from ADR-15 as it is right now:

> If no message or status is received within a certain time period, an alarm should be surfaced to the user in a way that makes sense in the client language, for example by notifying the user through the asynchronous error callback.

title: Rename create_stream to add_stream
body:
PR to make API more consisten with Go client.

I also moved around fn's in `impl JetStream` to have them grouped, though git make the diff little confusing.

title: Move Consumer Management to JetStream
body: First step to get rid of Consumer as it is now.

title: Improve error handling
body:
This takes some steps towards improving `JetStream` error handling.

- Box `jetstream::Error` into `io::Error`
- Adds error codes to `jetstream::Error` (generated from errors.json and edited a little bit)

title: Add support for JetStream publishing
body:
This adds adds support for `JetStream` publishing.
A few tangental fixes were made along the way.

Supercedes #218 
Closes #215

title: Introduce a `JetStream` type
body:
First pass at separating JetStream from `Connection`.

- Moves JetStreamOptions into the `jetstream` module.
- Introduces a `jetstream::JetStream` type that will be the home of `publish` with acks and other ops ala the Go and JavaScript clients.
- Adds a short-hand for instantiating these `JetStream` contexts via `nats::jetstream::new(nc)`.

Was considering `jetstream::Connection`, `jetstream::Client` and `jetstream::Context` and in the end just went with `jetstream::JetStream` but is bike-shreddable.

Easiest to review on a commit by commit basis.

title: Allow setting a jetstream api prefix from a domain
body: https://github.com/nats-io/nats-architecture-and-design/issues/52

title: Add domain field to `PubAck`
body: See https://github.com/nats-io/nats-architecture-and-design/issues/44

title: Allow for inline header description with spaces
Bump MSRV to 1.52.0
body: This bumpos the minimum supported rust version to 1.52.0 which is required for `str::split_once`.

title: Add support for continuation lines in `Headers::try_from`
Add a cargo format check job
Use stable toolchain for clippy checks
body: Switches the toolchain from nightly to stable to avoid any unexpected surprises.

title: Parse inline status and description in `Headers::try_from`
Various Updates.
body:
1. Went back to 100 line length for source code.
2. Reworked how we track internal servers, use url now.
3. Formalized setting up and running servers for tests. These can run in parallel now as well.
4. Add no responders support, fixes #219.
5. Added support for user and password in url, fixes #216.
6. Removed consumer based de-dupe which was ill-advised, fixes #225.
7. Added in periodic pings and client disconnect and cleanup.

Signed-off-by: Derek Collison <derek@nats.io>

title: Proposed update to enable reconnect on first attempt
body:
We have had issues connecting on the first attempt, similar to issue brought up in the past:
https://github.com/nats-io/nats.rs/issues/99

We modified the nats.rs to enable us to enter the retry loop on the first connection attempt.  Our application behavior is such that we do not require the NatsServer be up and running when we start.  This change allows for that behavior.

title: Test server subject matching bug fix
body:
Subject matching function in test server was only taking into account the number of tokens in message subject.

This caused false matches when a message's subject was a prefix of longer subscription pattern

title: auto-close async subscriptions
body: This addresses the comments from https://github.com/nats-io/nats.rs/pull/209 and closes https://github.com/nats-io/nats.rs/issues/213.

title: Use i64 instead of isize for representing Go's time.Duration type. Closes #208.
ADR-15-compatible js ack reply subject parsing
Add manual TLS config provision method for cases where certificates are unable to be passed-in manually. Closes #204.
Add test that demonstrates the functionality of queue subscribers
Fix small bug with JS serialization efficiency
Make jetstream generally available, and remove the jetstream feature
Merge the async_nats crate into the nats crate under the asynk module
Expose current server max_payload from Connection::max_payload
Add proper ipv6 address parsing support
Reset client writer to None upon disconnection from server
body: Fixes https://github.com/nats-io/nats.rs/issues/182

title: Doc-only update of async_nats::Subscription
body: documents the requirement to manually await `async_nats::Subscription::unsubscribe` due to Rust's lack of `AsyncDrop`, mentioned in https://github.com/nats-io/nats.rs/issues/179#issuecomment-843987681

title: Idempotent UNSUB avoids sending multiple UNSUB messages when subscrip…
body: …tions are dropped or manually unsubscribed.

title: Use fine-grained locking on read and write-related state
body:
This is the real fix for the issue encountered in benchmarks where subscriptions would cause lock-ups due to slow consumers.

This comes with the introduction of a mandatory locking protocol which must always be followed to avoid deadlocks going forward. But this is important for allowing reads and writes to make progress independently of each other, and the situations that require both locks to be held are pretty infrequent.

title: Add async request_timeout
body:
- Add support for request_timeout in async nats

Why: 
- If we get disconnected from NATS for reason, as the lib use unblock() under the hood, the application will leak threads waiting for the operation to receive a reply that will never comeback.
- Even if we get back the connection to NATS, those threads are lost in the limbo as they will never be able to receive a reply
- Wrapping `async request` within a futures::timeout, works but does not kill the underlying threads used by unblock

What:
- The PR exposes the `request_timeout` function in async-nats

title: Use multiple connections in the nats_bench example
Add min, max, and gaps methods to IntervalTree
Add support for static creds parsing
body: cc @autodidaddict

title: A few small cleanups, including a compilation fix for a future-incompatible example
body:
* add CI test to ensure examples always compile
* fix future incompatibility issue while using the log macro in a match arm
* avoid using a result in a return type for infallibly closing a connection

title: Use unpacked split-debuginfo for speeding up macos builds of the crate.
body: context: https://jakedeichert.com/blog/reducing-rust-incremental-compilation-times-on-macos-by-70-percent/

title: Don't split a header into more than two parts
body: Fixes issue #166.

title: Cut 0.9.9. Closes #163.
body:
Fixes two JetStream related bugs:

- #164 `Consumer::process_timeout` properly times out
  from all branches.
- #164 `Consumer::pull_opt` now properly checks the
  `Consumer.deliver_subject`.

title: Give access to Subscription's crossbeam channel
body:
Gives access to the a crossbeam Receiver in the Subscription struct. Useful for [crossbeam_channel::select][0] macro. Diff should speak for itself. I didn't find a way to select on multiple Subscriptions in one thread without access to the crossbeam channel. Is there a better way? 

Offtopic: I used the async-nats with tokio at first, but I think [async_nats::Subsciption::next][1] implementation will lose messages if canceled by [tokio::select][2].

[0]: https://docs.rs/crossbeam-channel/0.5.0/crossbeam_channel/macro.select.html
[1]: https://github.com/nats-io/nats.rs/blob/master/async-nats/src/lib.rs#L285
[2]: https://docs.rs/tokio/0.2.18/tokio/macro.select.html

title: error on unsupported header publish. Closes #159. Closes #160.
Cut 0.9.5 which allows JetStream early access via the jetstream feature
Fix the no_echo setting
body:
Just a really silly bug... The "echo" option was specified only when set to true, but it should've been specified when it's false because true is the default. Now we always specify it in the NATS protocol.

Fixes #147
